messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:12): othermaciej: http://www.w3.org/mid/<email/> is another report on the ease of use of the rel registry, effectively
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:13): I get an error message.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:15): ok i finally got a reply from microsoft
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:15): they intend to completely violate HTTP and just completely ignore the MIME type for <video>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:15): so i guess we know where they stand on standards compliance
c0a6c470e31cd9d911b5082260cdca10 (21:16): I'm only 27, I shouldn't be so jaded, but i kinda expected it.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:16): Isn't that what everyone does for images already, for example?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:16): yes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:16): but microsoft were on a "honour mime types" kick recently
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:16): so there was still hope
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:17): now the question is can i hold the other browsers back, or should i just give up and make <video> sniff for everything
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:17): and if the latter, can i get something specced that says how to recognise the video types
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:17): I thought we concluded that honoring MIME types for video was only useful for theoretical purity anyway.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:17): and can we get WebM changed to lost its leading ASCII nonsense (matroska would be a lost cause presumably)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:17): to lose, rather
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:18): well it's useful for avoiding tons of network wastage
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (21:18): btw, 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, not sure if I mentioned it, but I got TLS/SSL websockets working
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:18): since you don't have to download the bytes if you know the type is one you don't support
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:18): Everyone is still honoring <source type="">, no?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:18): haven't checked that
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:18): Once you can read the MIME type from the network, you can already read the first handful of bytes anyway.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:19): Unless you send a separate HEAD, which is a waste of a round trip.
c0a6c470e31cd9d911b5082260cdca10 (21:20): Some UA do that tho.
c0a6c470e31cd9d911b5082260cdca10 (21:20): Iinm proxies too.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:20): if anyone wants to test whether browsers (and IE9 in particular) honour <Source type>, that wouldn't be a bad thing to test
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:21): i might test it when i get back

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:49): CSS defines such things, I think, but I don't know if they work yet.
d0cc770ae91af3b856900c3bdfb79bb5 (21:50): hm
70146b691c63925cce03ef59b5c93127 (21:50): there are no list-style like that, but css generated content should work
